<title level="1" right="Rules">[Intelligent Items](/Rules.aspx?ID=3235)</title>

**Source** [GM Core](/Sources.aspx?ID=218) pg. 304 <sup>2.0</sup>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">
Magic items with a mind of their own have been a hallmark of myth and fantasy for millennia. When integrated into a campaign, they can become memorable characters in their own right.

Intelligent items are a special kind of magic item that straddles the line between treasure and NPC. An intelligent item might be another type of item as well: it could be an [artifact](/Rules.aspx?ID=3230) (like [Serithtial](/Equipment.aspx?ID=3123)), a [cursed item](/Rules.aspx?ID=3245), or even a [relic](/Rules.aspx?ID=3248) that grows with its wielder.

Introducing an intelligent item is an effective way to subtly alter the party dynamic. An intelligent item works well when its personality makes it a natural complement or foil for its partner: the PC [investing](/Rules.aspx?ID=3138), holding, or otherwise interacting with the item. An intelligent item that can communicate only with that particular PC is also a great way to engage players who are a bit quieter, or those slower to speak in a scene where all the PCs can talk to a particular NPC. Due to their inherently limited agency, intelligent items are at less of a risk for stealing the spotlight than other NPCs who travel along with the party.
</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>
